ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BANKRUPTS
(Raising of financial limit for discharge by certificate)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chng Hee Kok-

    1. To ask the Minister for Law if he will consider raising the financial limit under which the Official Assignee can grant a bankrupt discharge by certificate.

     The Minister of State for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, after a recent review of the implementation of the amended Bankruptcy Act, we have decided to increase the financial limit from $100,000 to $250,000. This will come into effect on 15th September this year.

    Sir, in 1995 we made major amendments to the Bankruptcy Act. The Official Assignee could exercise his discretion to discharge a bankrupt by certificate if his debt does not exceed $100,000. With this amendment, some 4,352 bankrupts have been able to obtain their discharges in the last two years.

    As at end June 1997, the Official Assignee has issued 11,636 notices of his intention to discharge bankrupts by his certificate. There were objections from the creditors in only 592 or 5.1% of the cases and few have challenged the Official Assignee's decision in the Courts.

    We believe that the new provision has worked well. We started with the financial limit of $100,000 for the Official Assignee to issue a certificate of discharge. In the light of experience gained, we are satisfied that we can now raise it to $250,000. The Official Assignee will continue to apply the same criteria to select cases for discharge, balancing the interests of both creditors and bankrupts. These are the cause of bankruptcy, age of the bankrupt and of the bankruptcy, the bankrupt's conduct, his contributions to his bankruptcy estate and the extent of cooperation extended to the Official Assignee. We hope that this will give an

Column: 1522

added incentive to bankrupts to make greater efforts to work towards their discharge from bankruptcy.

SINGAPORE CIVIL DEFENCE FORCE AMBULANCES
(Raising of charges in non-emergency cases)


    2. Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the reasons for raising the charges for the use of Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) ambulances in non-emergency cases, given that there will be a concerted publicity campaign to encourage people to use the service provided by Commercial and Industrial Security Corporation (CISCO); and whether the SCDF can, as an alternative measure, re-route calls to CISCO when non-emergency cases are involved.

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Civil Defence Force's Emergency Ambulance Service (EAS) is primarily intended for response to life-threatening emergencies. SCDF ambulances are thus equipped with state-of-the-art equipment such as defibrillators and other resuscitative devices, and ambulance crews are specially trained to give basic life support to the seriously injured or sick. SCDF currently charges only $50 for each non-emergency call, although the full cost is $110 each time one of our ambulances is called out. Most private ambulance operators currently charge $50 to $70 per trip, but their ambulances are not similarly equipped.

    The EAS is increasingly being misused by the public, despite SCDF's sustained public education efforts. Although emergency calls have hovered around 40,000 per year over the last five years, non-emergency calls have nearly doubled - 11,000 in 1992 to 20,000 calls last year. Another way of looking at this is that roughly 1 out of every 3 ambulance calls was unnecessarily handled by the SCDF, when a private ambulance or even a taxi would have served the purpose.

Column: 1523



    Each time the EAS attends to a non-emergency call, it is less able to respond in time to a real emergency. We must take decisive steps to stop this abuse. Our approach is two-pronged. First, SCDF has helped to set up a private non-emergency ambulance hotline, 777-0000, currently operated by CISCO. SCDF has widely publicised it, using the mass media as well as distributing brochures to every household. We have achieved modest results so far. But we need to do more to encourage the public to switch over and call for private ambulances when they do not have an emergency on hand.

    Secondly, from October 1997, every non-emergency EAS user will be billed $75, which barely recovers three quarters of the cost. From October 1998, non-emergency users will have to bear the full cost, which will be at least $110. Many countries such as the United States, Canada and Australia are charging full cost for their non-emergency ambulance services so that critical resources are properly allocated. Indeed, users even have to pay for emergency ambulance services in these countries.

    SCDF already re-routes an average of 10 to 15 calls a day to the CISCO hotline. But this still unnecessarily involves the SCDF and is only a small fraction of the number of non-emergency calls received by it. The measures we are introducing will have greater impact. They are designed to relieve the SCDF of unnecessarily taking calls or attending to non-emergency cases, so that it can be more effective in its core responsibility of attending to real emergencies.

     Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, can the Minister of State explain how a decision is made between non-emergency cases and emergency cases? Who decides?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, in a large percentage of cases it is not possible to ascertain on the telephone whether it is an emergency or non-emergency case. Indeed, when a person calls the SCDF he will say that it is something that requires attention straightaway. In these cases, SCDF will not take the risk and they will go

Column: 1524

to the ground. There is a staff nurse who is well trained and there are guidelines. In instances when it is non-life threatening, for example, a headache or backache or sometimes a bad toothache, and so forth, the user will be told that it is a non-emergency situation. If the person insists that it is an emergency and he must get to the hospital straightaway, SCDF nevertheless will take him to the hospital. After which, SCDF will check with the hospital and the doctor, having treated the person, will tell us the situation. If it is a non-emergency case, we will treat it as such.

Column: 1524

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Assistance for upgraders in selling their existing flats)


    3. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for National Development in what ways the Housing and Development Board can help those upgraders who have encountered great difficulties in selling their existing flats as a result of the recent policy change.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the revised policies announced in April and May this year are not intended to decrease the liquidity of HDB flats and stifle the HDB resale market. HDB's records show that the number of resale transactions since the announcements in April and May has not dropped significantly. There are about 3,200 and 3,000 flats registered for resale in the months of June and July respectively. These figures are close to the monthly average of 3,300 applications received last year. Therefore, the revised policies have led to a consolidation of the HDB resale market, without significantly affecting the demand for these flats.

    HDB resale flat prices have been experiencing a sharp upward turn in the past few years, with annual increases of about 35% in the last two years. We cannot expect such increases to continue year after year. A consolidation of prices would place the HDB resale market on a firmer footing.

Column: 1525



    In general, price movements of HDB resale flats will be determined by the market forces of demand and supply, as well as the prevailing market sentiments. Therefore, HDB flat owners should still be able to find buyers for their flats, provided their asking prices reflect these market considerations.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, can I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether he is aware that the market prices of HDB resale flats since the announcement of the revised policies have dropped significantly and, in some cases, up to 20%? Would he consider this drop as a consolidation of prices?

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, since 1992, prices of HDB flats have risen quite high. In fact, I recall, sitting on the other side of the Bench for the last five years, that Members have been screaming that HDB flat prices have shot through the roof. I just said that in the last two years, HDB resale flat prices went up by 35% alone. This adjustment downwards from a very high benchmark is a consolidation. It is not excessive. It is not significant.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Can I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether he would still consider it as consolidation if the prices of HDB resale flats drop to valuation or below valuation?

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, I think it is still consolidation. I will give him some numbers. In July 1997, ie, 2-3 months after the two announcements made in April and May, the number of resale transactions registered with valuation, that means resale transactions with valuation reports, totalled 1,855. 1.7% or 32 out of the 1,855 resale applications registered with valuations were sold at prices below valuation. In other words, only 1.7% of the 1,855 resale flats with valuation reports were sold below valuation. The majority of them, 98.3%, were sold at or above valuation prices.

    Of these few cases which were sold below valuation, the difference between the valuation price and the asking price

Column: 1526

was only about 5%. So the figure is not alarming. In any case, the valuations are only a guideline. They are not numbers tabulated in stone that cannot be changed. In fact, valuation reports are very much like topographic maps. Very often, when a map is published it is out of date. In the case of a valuation report, in many cases, when it is published it may also be out of date.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary confirm that, in fact, valuation reports are made for the purposes of getting loans and the reports do not reflect the open market value? The valuation report is about 20% less than the market value. If the sale is below the valuation report, then it will be greater than 20%.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: The buyer has the option of selecting a professional valuer from the HDB's list. So these valuation figures are not provided by HDB. They are provided by professional valuers unless he is questioning the judgment of these professional valuers. The market prices change from time to time. Over the last few months, prices of HDB resale flats have fallen slightly but not significantly. In the case of a falling market, the valuation prices will always lead the asking price. Just like in a rising market, valuation prices will usually lag the asking prices.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I have done many cases concerning valuation of HDB flats and all these valuations are for purposes of raising mortgage loans. Therefore, they do not reflect the open market price of the flat. It is only about 80%, because HDB only gives a loan of about 80% of the open market price. So the valuation report as it is does not reflect the open market price of the flat. It is about 20% less. Even if you sell at valuation, it is already 20% less than the open market value.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, that is not the case. Valuation prices are valuation reports.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Sir, can I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether such a drop in prices in such a short time had been anticipated by the Ministry when

Column: 1527

implementing the new policies? Because such a drop in prices has affected a large number of Singaporeans selling their flats at that particular point of time and a lot of them were actually caught. The Parliamentary Secretary may not be aware but there are many persons selling their flats during this period of time and conducting open houses who did not get any call at all.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, during the Budget debate, the Minister for National Development has given a very clear and concise assessment of the property market since the announcement of the two policies in April and May. In the case of Dr Wang, I understand that some of his residents have difficulty selling their HDB flats at or above the valuation prices. In fact, HDB allows a six-month period for the person who has taken possession of the new flat to sell his existing flat. So his resident has six months to sell the flat. If at the end of six months, he still cannot sell the flat HDB, on a case by case basis, does allow another six months for him to sell the flat provided attempts have been made by the seller to sell on the market seriously. In other words, such evidence could be newspaper advertisements or reports from housing agents. In all, it could be a one-year period. So within that year, a serious seller asking for a reasonable price should be able to sell his flat.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary for his opinion. In view of the drop in the selling prices of HDB flats after the election, does the situation now tie in well with the PAP's asset enhancement scheme, as proposed at the last election?

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: The answer is yes. The Government has increased the assets of the overwhelming majority of Singaporeans. I will give an example. The selling price of a 3-room flat, which formed the bulk of the flats sold in the early years, was between $8,000 and $15,000. My parents' flat, for example, was sold, if I remember correctly, at about $10,000. Today, those 3-room flats are now sold on the open market at about $200,000. If you do not call that an asset enhancement, what is that? Even if they

Column: 1528

drop a little bit, 5%, 7%, or 10% from $200,000, it is a significant increase from $10,000. Does he not agree? Does he not call that asset enhancement?

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: In other words, the Parliamentary Secretary's view is that even if the selling price of a HDB flat were to drop by another 30%, he will still consider it an asset enhancement.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a hypothetical question. I will not dignify that with a reply. HDB flats have not fallen by 30%. It has consolidated itself and I think the volume of resale transactions proves that the market is adjusting quite nicely.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Sir, I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether his Ministry is considering any measure to help people sell their flats at higher prices and whether the Government's planned land sales have any impact on these HDB flats.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: The HDB's building programme has been announced and the information is there. The people who buy and sell HDB resale flats based on this information should understand that prices can go up and they can also come down. And over the last 30 years, prices have on the whole gone up quite significantly. Right now, it is consolidating itself. It has still gone up by quite a lot if you look at the base figures from 1992-1996 and even the first quarter of 1997.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, those who bought HDB flats from the resale open market before the general election actually paid higher prices than what the flat is worth now. I do not know whether the Parliamentary Secretary is of the view that it is still an asset enhancement.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Property prices go up and down. The economy is on the way to recovery. I think in the long term property in Singapore will only go up. But in the short term, there could be fluctuations. But we should look at the long term. Property is something that is not movable and is held for posterity.

Column: 1529



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, HDB flats are public housing. The Parliamentary Secretary says that prices move up and down. So there is a speculative element in it. Does the Government allow this speculative element to continue in public housing?

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: You cannot say that there is a speculative element. Resale prices of HDB flats go up and down according to demand and supply and the state of the economy. And HDB has never said that prices can only go up.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: The Parliamentary Secretary did not answer my question on whether the land sales programme affects HDB prices.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee: I want to repeat that the Ministry of National Development publishes its land sales programme and the number of units HDB will build, and based on these figures, the market will react to it. It is not for HDB or the Government to influence prices. We cannot do it. It is beyond our control. He is asking whether HDB will help the sellers fetch a higher resale price. You tell me how?

Column: 1529

TRAINED HEALTHCARE WORKERS
(Adequacy)


    4. Mr Ang Mong Seng asked the Minister for Health whether there are adequate numbers of trained healthcare workers to look after our greying population and the subsidised transport needs of needy elderly citizens who have to attend regular medical check-ups at the hospitals; and whether the revised ambulance charges will affect them.

     The Senior Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Most of the elderly are healthy. For the sick and dependent elderly, they require different levels and types of care which are provided by the family members as well as healthcare professionals. The Ministry is coordinating special training programmes for healthcare professionals and home carers to cater to the special needs of the elderly. These include:

Column: 1530



    Firstly, geriatricians, who are physicians who sub-specialise in medical care of the elderly. They usually work in geriatric departments in acute hospitals. As geriatric care is a relatively new specialty in Singapore, we are in the process of training more doctors in this specialty. There are currently 15 geriatricians in Singapore, with another five in training. We target to have 23 geriatricians by the year 2000.

    Secondly, general practitioners play a major role in looking after the elderly. The School of Postgraduate Medical Studies is starting a Postgraduate Diploma course in geriatric medicine in September this year. This one year course which incorporates elements of distance-learning will allow many more doctors to be better trained in looking after the elderly.

    Thirdly, nurses who have undergone post-basic training in gerontology. Currently, 117 nurses have advanced diplomas in gerontology. The Nanyang Polytechnic's School of Health Sciences is able to train about 25 registered nurses in this advanced diploma course every year. There is also a course for assistant nurses run by the School of Nursing on Care of the Elderly to complement the registered nurses.

    Fourthly, nursing aides are trained in simple nursing skills relevant to the needs of the elderly.

    Finally, community-based service providers do provide training for family carers to look after their sick elderly at home.

    As to the second part of Mr Ang's question, the ambulance service by the Singapore Civil Defence Forces (SCDF) is provided for emergencies. The increase in charges by the SCDF from $50 to $75 refers to non-emergencies who use these ambulances. The elderly who require transport for routine medical check-ups at hospitals and clinics are not affected by the SCDF's increased ambulance charges, as in the first place, they should not be using those ambulances.

Column: 1531

DEGREE PROGRAMMES FOR NURSING IN LOCAL UNIVERSITIES


    5. Dr Toh See Kiat asked the Minister for Health since upgrading the Certificate in Nursing to a polytechnic diploma has improved the image of the nursing profession and consequently the intake of nurses, whether there are any plans to introduce degree programmes for nursing in the local universities.

     Dr Aline Wong (for the Minister for Health): At present, there is no full-time local degree programme for nursing. But there is a 2-year, part-time Bachelor of Nursing degree programme offered by the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) which was introduced in September 1994.

    Nurses who have acquired the Nanyang Polytechnic (NYP) Diploma in Nursing can proceed to the degree programme either locally at the SIM or at the University of Sydney itself. Nurses can apply for sponsorship from their employer, be it the Ministry of Health, the restructured hospitals or private hospitals, to enrol in this programme. We will continue to sponsor nurses who show the ability and aptitude for greater responsibility to participate in the programme.

    The degree programme at SIM has managed to take in, on average, about 140 students per year in the last three years. The first year's intake has already completed their programme. This programme will provide us with a steady supply of graduate nurses to meet our requirements in the immediate future. We will monitor the demand for the degree programme by the healthcare institutions and by the nurses. This will help us gauge whether there is a need for a full-time local degree programme.

    My Ministry is also aware that there are good `A' level students who wish to take up nursing as a career. For these young people, PSC offers scholarships tenable in the UK and Australia. Thus far, 28 nursing scholars have returned and are working in MOH and the restructured hospitals. Another four PSC scholars are still pursuing their degree. A small number of World Health Organisation scholarships are also available.

Column: 1532



     Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar): I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State how readily available are these sponsorships for Singaporeans who are interested to pursue a nursing degree in Sydney. Does she have any statistics?

     Dr Aline Wong: The degree course for nursing at Sydney is not normally open to sponsorship, unless private institutions or restructured hospitals want to sponsor the students this way. This is because the course is already available locally at SIM. But I think he is talking more about PSC scholarships. These are offered only to people who qualify for them. Students can apply but the PSC will select.

     Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Sir, basically, I raise this question because we have been debating about the need to upgrade the image of nurses and because of the fact that nurses are treated more like drudges in Singapore. This is unfortunate because it is a high calling, and we need to upgrade this dignity.

     Mr Speaker: Order. Dr Toh, can you ask your question?

     Dr Toh See Kiat: Yes. Sir, I would like to urge the Ministry to perhaps consider whether there is this need to push the PSC programme so that we will have more scholars who are nurses and nursing can become a dignified profession again.

     Dr Aline Wong: PSC scholarships are for people who do very well academically and want to take up nursing as a career. The number of scholarships also depends on how many are willing to take them up. But in general, Dr Toh's concern, I believe, is about raising the professional status and prestige of the nurses. There are other ways. For nurses to take up degree training, we have to consider whether they have the ability as well as the readiness to take up greater responsibility in the post. So the nursing degree is not really for everyone.

Column: 1532
